awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Electronic Structure and Reactivity of Peroxo- and Hydroxomanganese Compounds
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Timothy Jackson of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Kansas is investigating new manganese peroxo and hydroxo complexes with interesting chemical reactivity.  The goal of this research is to determine how the structures of these manganese complexes can be controlled to impart a desired reaction.  This knowledge could be used to reduce the cost and environmental footprint of chemical transformations and will advance understanding of manganese enzymes in humans, plants, and bacteria. The project lies at the interface of inorganic, physical and biological chemistry, and provides a training experience for graduate and undergraduate students. Trips to national laboratories to perform X-ray absorption experiments afford training in synchrotron radiation, including radiation safety training. This research is disseminated to the general public via presentations at University Orientation Days, the University Mini-College, and Science on Tap. In these forums, a broad, general audience engages with on-going chemical research. Spectroscopic and theoretical methods used in this research is incorporated into graduate and undergraduate courses. This research has relevance to sustainable chemistry because it uses less toxic and more abundant manganese complexes.

Manganese(III)-peroxo adducts are frequently proposed as intermediates in the formation of high-valent manganese-oxo species in synthetic oxidation catalysts. Manganese(III)-hydroxo motifs are known to participate in biologically important proton-coupled electron-transfer reactions.  However, the influence of geometric and electronic structure on the reactivity of these compounds is not well defined. Specific aims of the project include: 1) investigation of the O-O bond activation pathways of a manganese(III)-peroxo adduct support by an oxidatively robust ligand; 2) exploration of ligand effects on the reductive activation of manganese(III)-peroxo adducts; and 3) a systematic variation of the ligand field of manganese(III)-hydroxo complexes to develop correlations between electronic structure perturbations and chemical reactivity.  Through this work, molecular-level insight into the activation of peroxomanganese(III) species for oxygen (O)-O bond cleavage through chemical and electrochemical pathways are developed.  In addition, the proton-coupled electron transfer reactions of mid-valent hydroxomanganese(III) species are explored.  In an undergraduate bioinorganic course,
students will develop video modules describing relevant physical methods. The methods used in this research are incorporated into graduate and undergraduate courses. The results of this work are disseminated broadly through University and community outreach activities.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of this project were to develop a better understanding of the chemical reactivity of manganese-peroxo and manganese-hydroxo complexes. Such complexes are commonly found as intermediates in biological and synthetic manganese catalysts. In biological systems, manganese-peroxo and manganese-hydroxo intermediates have been proposed in the catalytic cycle of the enzyme manganese superoxide dismutase, which defends a variety of organisms, including humans, from the deleterious effects of free radicals. In addition, manganese-peroxo species are proposed as intermediates in manganese-based oxidation catalysts. Such catalysts are less expensive and more environmentally friendly than conventional oxidation processes and therefore offer a pathway for more sustainable chemical transformations. Thus, the intellectual merits of this work span the fields of biology and chemistry.

In this project, we successfully generated and characterized a series of manganese-hydroxo complexes with systematically altered properties. We used both experimental and quantum chemical methods to understand how these variations in properties were correlated to changes in chemical reactivity. This work allowed us to understand how the local environment of a manganese-hydroxo complex can be changed to enhance its reactivity. These findings help to understand the reactivity of some manganese-dependent enzymes. We were also able to apply various spectroscopic measurements to understand equilibrium reactions of manganese-hydroxo species in solution. These experiments will be helpful to scientists seeking to understand the speciation of manganese centers in solution, which is often very important information for understanding the complex reactions of synthetic manganese catalysts. We also identified new manganese-peroxo complexes that showed high sensitivity to added acids. This accomplishment highlighted a new mode of reactivity for manganese-peroxo compounds.

This project also provide excellent training opportunities for a variety of graduate and undergraduate students. These students were involved in disseminating the results of this work in the form of peer-reviewed publications and presentations at professional conferences. The research support afforded by the project contributed to two students receiving their Ph.D. degrees and one student receiving his M.S. degree. More broadly, outreach efforts associated with this project engaged elementary school students using chemical demonstrates and discussions that explored the properties of transition metals and oxygen.


Last Modified: 12/17/2020
Modified by: Timothy Jackson
